titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Love Family Papers
titlestmt.author: Compiled and edited by Catherine Buckwalder under the supervision of Francis Radvonovsky

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 07:00

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: Correspondence, printed materials, theater programs, photographs and other papers of Lucy Cleveland Prindle Love and Helen Douglas Love Scranton, wife and daughter, respectively, of Edward Gurley Love and active in New York social and cultural life in the early 20th century.The correspondence is chiefly from theatrical personalities and writers and concerns cultural life in New York City. Prominent among the correspondents are Pearl S. Buck, Andrew Carnegie, Thomas Alva Edison, Clara Clemens, Helen Keller, Kate Douglas Wiggin Riggs, Jules Verne and Alexander Woollcott.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Love Family Papers (MS 12). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the estate of Helen Douglas Love Scranton, l969.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: I. Correspondence. II. Miscellaneous. III. Printed Materials. IV. Photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Love Family Papers consist primarily of letters to Lucy Cleveland Prindle Love (Mrs. Edward Gurley Love) and a lesser amount to her daughter, Helen Douglas (Love) Scranton, written during the early and middle years of the twentieth century. Many of the letters are from theatrical personalities and authors as Dame Sybil Thorndike, Kate Douglas Wiggin and Ben Greet (Sir Philip Ben Greet, 1857-1936), and comment on various cultural activities in New York City and America. Mrs. Love was the wife of Edward Gurley Love, a chemical engineer who held a Ph.D. from Columbia University. A graduate of Hamilton College (1822), he received the Ph.B. from Columbia in 1876 and the Ph.D. in 1876. In 1877, he was appointed to the newly created post of gas examiner for New York City. During World War I, Mr. Love worked for the U.S. Government and constructed a large plant for the recovery of toluol from the gas used for city lighting, the product being used for the manufacture of TNT.

The Loves lived on the East Side of Manhattan and their interest in the arts is evident in this collection of Mrs. Love's correspondence, much of which concerns a production of PARSIFAL given in 1904 which she supported. Her daughter, Helen, was Secretary of the Society of the Friends of Music and most of her correspondence is related to the placing of subscriptions by prominent social personalities of the day such as William Lyon Phelps. Helen (Love) Scranton was the second wife of William Dowd Scranton, an 1897 graduate of Sheffield Scientific School, Yale University, and later lived in Madison, Connecticut. Historically, the papers would be of greatest interest to the student of theater history. The Ben Greet correspondence is the largest file in the collection and at one time Mrs. Scranton considered writing a biography based in part on these papers. These papers would also furnish source material for the social historian interested in the development of New York City as a leading cultural center of the world during the early part of this century. The Love Family Papers were left to the Yale University Library by the estate of Helen (Love) Scranton in 1969.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown, though much of the material in this collection is likely in the public domain. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

controlaccess.persname: Scranton, Helen D. Love (Helen Douglas Love), 1879-1968

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence is arranged in alphabetical order by last name of the sender or recipient. Within each folder, the letters are then placed in chronological order.

People included in the correspondence are: Pearl S. Buck, Andrew Carnegie, Thomas Alva Edison, Clara (Clemens) Babrilowilsch, Hamlin Garland, Herbert Hoover, Helen Keller, Kate Douglas (Wiggin) Riggs, Jules Verne, A.H. Woolcott and many other noted people.
Unidentified material is grouped together in a folder found alphabetically under U, and is in chronological order with undated material at the end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Included in this series are an essay entitled "Dictations on Art" by Lulu C. Love, checks, receipts from the Kneisel Quartet, sketches and autographs of William Dean Howells, Jules Verne, Ben Greet and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is arranged in alphabetical order by name of subject or type of material with miscellaneous and unidentified material at the end. Included are a pictorial souvenir of Maude Adams in "L'Aiglon", publicity material for Harold Bauer, Ben Greet, Mr. & Mrs. Charles Hopkins and Vivien George, theater programs, and wedding and burial announcements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs are arranged in alphabetical order by the subjects' last names. Unidentified photos are at the end of the series.
These photos consist of individuals such as Harold Bauer, Ben Greet, Kate Douglas (Wiggin) Riggs, and others who figure prominently in collection.
